body:
Hmm, I'm not quite seeing it.  I added ValueProvider to the branch (which is getting type, which is from genericReturnType, as far as I can tell), I'm still losing parameters:

java.lang.RuntimeException: Unable to derive type for ValueProvider: [simple type, class org.apache.beam.sdk.options.ValueProvider]
    at org.apache.beam.sdk.options.ValueProvider$Deserializer.createContextual(ValueProvider.java:177)

Separately, for the ID, it seems like I can't add it to PIpelineOptions, since it's an interface.  Would using ProxyInvocationHandler, along with its unique hash code, be reasonable?
I think you'll need to do more investigation as this is just taking up too much time as a reviewer
R: @dhalperi addressed comments.
R: @markflyhigh  @jasonkuster
Fixed

Minor nits, but LGTM at this point.

In addition to nits, if you have time I'd appreciate two quick passes:
- do a minor review of Javadoc everywhere. I still see some empty blocks for top-level classes (`UnboundedSource` eg)
- throw useful errors. Overall good, but there are still lots of `checkNotNull(f)` which will not throw the most useful exception.

Let me know when you're ready for me to push. The only "mandatory" comments are the ones in the pom.xml
Thanks!
@tweise I have same issues in other PRs.

Please update [`findbugs-filter.xml`](https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/blob/master/sdks/java/build-tools/src/main/resources/beam/findbugs-filter.xml#L34) to remove the exclusion for this. Otherwise LGTM.

Changes Unknown when pulling **2efe7617a595b8ac6167db40724d9874afd6df23 on francesperry:master** into *\* on apache:master**.

Apologies, I still seem to be missing something.  I'm filtering duplicates (or intending to) by checking equality with the bean class, but getting a raft of failures:

Stacktrace was: java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: Could not initialize class org.apache.beam.sdk.options.PipelineOptionsFactory

I don't think you want to pass in the `beanClass` at all as the list of methods should contain everything you need. The key here is that things should be matched by the `property` name to find getter/setters.

Validation about conflicting types should be done in `validateClass`.

As for your compilation issues, seems unrelated to the code but an issue with your development envrionment.

I'm sorry; I don't understand what delta you are requesting.  Are you
saying that I can remove the bean class matching and that the code should
otherwise work?

Empirically, the runtime failure has only started happening after using
allInterfaceMethods, so I'm not sure how it related to my environment.

On Aug 19, 2016 4:48 PM, "lukecwik" notifications@github.com wrote:

> I don't think you want to pass in the beanClass at all as the list of
> methods should contain everything you need. The key here is that things
> should be matched by the property name to find getter/setters.
> 
> Validation about conflicting types should be done in validateClass.
> 
> As for your compilation issues, seems unrelated to the code but an issue
> with your development envrionment.
> 
> 
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/pull/852#issuecomment-241130825,
> or mute the thread
> https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/ACQVgYKcxXW-s96DG6ttsujIc6waHNJHks5qhhZrgaJpZM4JoDfp
> .
@dhalperi fixed.

At a highlevel, what you noticed was that the methods from the interfaces retained their generic signatures yet the proxy class did not. You'll want to swap the uses of the proxy class methods to use the methods from the interfaces across `ProxyInvocationHandler` and `PipelineOptionsFactory` without breaking existing usecases.
LGTM!

guys, any updates ?
Yes, I rebased and tested. I noted some stuff to fix. I will comment today.

I rebased this on the current master and also added tests for the new `DoFnOperator` and `SideInputHandler`. This should be good to merge now from my side.

I'm quite confident that the Flink side is good now, I had to change some code in other parts, though, that would need review from someone knowledgeable in Beam. These changes are in the commits after the two main implementation commits. I'm thinking @tgroh, @dhalperi or @kennknowles  for this. If one of you would have a look that would be perfect. (The one I'm most unsure about is this one: ed1e01ac78793227168ec7a20f6a45cb8b5ba293).

Also, both `SideInputHandler` and `SideInputHandlerTest` would probably benefit from another pass over them.

Refactored and unit tested what i can. Still no excellent way to unit test BatchRequest. Not only can I not mock the `.batch()` call to create a batch, I also can't mock the `BatchRequest` object itself. And there's no getters on the BatchRequest that will let me inspect the request payloads.

I did run a job: 2016-08-21_23_12_50-10923575837433736309

Took 28s after side input initialization to copy the 10K files.

@amitsela @jbonofre 
Thanks Amit and no problem !
I've just came back from vacation so sorry for this late response. 

I think that the SparkRunner should just use the context as provided at the moment the Runner is created. The context stays external to the runner along with its state (running, stopped, ...) (we can add a `isStopped` call just before calling the execution logic to make sure that the context is up & running and fail the execution otherwise). This way the SparkRunner doesn't have to deal with the context's state and it doesn't matter if the context is an SJS or a shell one.

Thanks!

and then I had the log message printing some ConsumerConfig and then it printed infinetely:
...
[pool-1-thread-2] WARN org.apache.beam.sdk.io.kafka.KafkaIO - Reader-0: getWatermark() : no records have been read yet.
[pool-1-thread-4] WARN org.apache.beam.sdk.io.kafka.KafkaIO - Reader-0: getWatermark() : no records have been read yet. 
...

I am not sure that keeping the log message  is that useful (even if not receiving data could be seen as an exceptional situation in kafka, because we can change the log to the trace level but then the question is how useful this is, (printing a message saying no data received for the moment) indefinitely.
@manuzhang would you be available on Slack or Hangout ? I would like to discuss a couple of topics with you. Thanks !
@staslev please add apache license headers to all new files, once you push the changes Jenkins should retry.
@jbonofre or @iemejia you guys are using Spark, are you using the metrics system ? if so, you might find this interesting as well.
I used Graphite in the past yes. Let me take a look.
@jbonofre do you understand what's the issue with Jenkins ? I see `Apache Beam :: Parent`  failed, but for no apparent reason...
Let me check. I remember we got rat failure due to a heapdump.
It seems that one file in the PR doesn't contain license header (checking which one). RAT is failing.
Usually RAT produces a report, no ? if so, where is it ?
It looks like metrics.properties doesn't contain ASF license header.
The rat report is in target folder of the parent (in the workspace).
Thanks!

Thanks, sorry about that.
Didn't realise non java files needed to have the headers as well.
@staslev No worries. Yes, RAT checks any kind of file (however I excluded some files hard to check). Thanks !
